description: Borrowed from Italian miniatura (“manuscript illumination”), from miniare (“to illuminate”), from Latin miniō (“to colour red”), from minium (“red lead”).

adjectives.description: miniature (comparative more miniature, superlative most miniature)

examples: I find miniature dogs annoying; they seem to yap more than full-size dogs.

entries.meaning: Greatly diminished size or form; reduced scale.
A small version of something; a model of reduced scale.
examples: There was a miniature of a whaling ship in a glass bottle over the mantlepiece.

entries.meaning: A small, highly detailed painting, a portrait miniature.
The art of painting such highly detailed miniature works.
An illustration in an illuminated manuscript.
A musical composition which is short in duration.
examples: Sacha composed a miniature for strings as a final project at the conservatory.

entries.meaning: (chess) A chess game which is concluded with very few moves.
(role-playing games, board games) A token in a game representing a unit or character.
examples: Jack had dozens of miniatures of Napoleonic footsoldiers painted in detailed period regalia for his wargames.

verbs.description: miniature (third-person singular simple present miniatures, present participle miniaturing, simple past and past participle miniatured)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make smaller than normal; to reproduce in miniature.
